'Paraguay' (US , UK ), officially the 'Republic of Paraguay' ( , GuaranÃ­: TetÃ£
ParaguÃ¡i ), is a landlocked country located in South America, bordered by
Argentina to the south and southwest, Brazil to the east and northeast, and
Bolivia to the northwest. Paraguay lies on both banks of the Paraguay River,
which runs through the center of the country from north to south. Due to its
central location in South America, it is sometimes referred to as CorazÃ³n de
AmÃ©rica ("Heart of America").

The GuaranÃ­ have been living in Paraguay since before the arrival of Europeans
in the 16th century, when Paraguay became part of the Spanish colonial
empire. Following independence from Spain in 1811, Paraguay was ruled by a
series of dictators who followed isolationist and protectionist policies. This
development was truncated by the disastrous Paraguayan War (1864â1870) in which
the country lost 60% to 70% of its population and large amounts of territory.
During a large part of the 20th century, Paraguay was ruled by Alfredo
Stroessner, who led one of South America's longest lived military dictatorships.
In 1989 Stroessner was toppled and free elections were celebrated in 1993. A
year later, Paraguay joined Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay to found Mercosur.

As of 2009, Paraguay's population was estimated to be at around
6.5 million, most of whom are concentrated in the southeast of the country.
The capital and largest city is AsunciÃ³n, whose metropolitan area is home to
nearly a third of the population. In contrast to most Latin American countries,
the indigenous language and culture remain widespread, and the majority of
Paraguayans are mestizo. The official languages are Spanish and GuaranÃ­, both of
which are widely spoken in the country, with around 92% of the general
population speaking Spanish and 98% speaking GuaranÃ­.

Paraguay has long been one of the region's poorest, least-developed, and most
isolated countries. In 2010, the economy grew by 14.5%, the largest economic
expansion in Latin America, and the third fastest in the world (after Qatar and
Singapore). CIA > Accessed on 19 September 2011. By 2011, economic growth had slowed
to 6.4%, still far higher than the global average.
